This is your opportunity to contribute to the multi-chain future of the Maker ecosystem.

Spark Protocol is going multi-chain, and preparing for its deployments across diverse domains.

If you're interested in deploying Spark Protocol in a specific domain, follow these steps:

↓

First, what are domains?

When we mention 'domains,' we are referring to various blockchain networks, including sidechains and layer 2 solutions.

Now, let's see how to propose a domain deployment for Spark:

The interested domain should create a post on the Maker Forum under the SubDAO TWO category (https://lnkd.in/etmu6ZxH), with the following information:

1) Background Information:

• Who is the interested party for this new domain application?
• Provide a brief high-level overview of the chain
• Explain the business case of having Spark deployed in the new domain.

2) Technical Information:

• Does your team can work on the cross-chain support for L2 Executor and Crosschain Forwarder?
• How long will this take?
• List other technical requirements

3) Collaterals Information

• What would be the initially proposed collaterals besides DAI?

For each collateral please provide:

a. List any possible oracle data sources for the proposed collateral.
b. What is the market cap for the asset?
c. Where does exchange for the asset occur?

4) Liquidity information

• How are you planning to seed liquidity?

After the proposal submission, Phoenix Labs will conduct a domain assessment and offer recommendations to MakerDAO about the new domain and collaterals to be included.

It's essential to note that Spark will only onboard tokens previously approved by Maker.

Additionally, Block Analitica will perform a collateral assessment and suggest risk parameters for the collaterals within Spark in the new domain.

The domain and collateral assessments will be published on the Maker Forum.

These assessments will provide valuable insights for MKR holders when making decisions regarding the deployment of Spark on a new domain.

For a complete understanding, please refer to the original post on the Maker Forum:https://lnkd.in/esbZ6Q7JAlternatively, you can contact the Spark team on Discord:discord.gg/5DFmSaXWJ8.

Stay connected and be a part of this exciting expansion!

Phoenix Labs has proposed a multi-chain future for Spark!

Together, we will strive for the integration of Layer 2 solutions and the exploration of other blockchain networks.

Success lies in being where the users are.

This is a recap of Spark's multi-chain roadmap.

↓

Firstly, Phoenix Lab's proposal outlined key considerations for prioritizing Spark deployments on different chains:

1) Business Case:

Blockchain teams must present a compelling rationale for why Allocators should provide debt capacity to a particular chain.

Allocators won't allocate resources if there is no significant product demand on that chain.

2) Scale:

Spark is looking for domains that can support substantial returns on a large scale, involving hundreds of millions of USD at decent yields.

3) Strategic Value:

Spark prioritizes domains that have strong connections with Maker or the potential to establish such connections within their ecosystem and community.

4) Security + Safety:

The level of venture risk determines the requirements for junior capital.
Spark will prioritize relatively secure chains with higher debt ceilings to maximize profitability.

Phoenix Labs will develop a roadmap that outlines the process of converting Spark Protocol into a multi-chain protocol.

The team has identified two phases to execute this new multi-chain future for Spark:

Phase 1: Permissionless Deployment

In this phase, a fresh instance of Spark Lend will be deployed on the remote chain in coordination with the developer team, ensuring minimal risk for users through a Governance Relay.

During Phase 1, borrow rates will be manually adjusted to closely align with Ethereum's rate.
Important to note:

Domains that are interested in participating should provide essential information in the forum under the SubDAO TWO category.

The forum link is provided below:https://lnkd.in/etmu6ZxHPhase 2: Spark Bridge Deployment

This phase allows AllocatorDAOs to deposit and withdraw funds from the existing Spark Lend instance across different chains.

The Spark Bridge utilizes canonical token bridges to ensure the most liquid version of DAI is utilized.

Withdrawals in Phase 2 are facilitated through AllocatorDAO requests, similar to RWA (Real-World Asset) investments.

A round-trip on the native bridge executes the withdrawal, subject to the availability of liquidity in the remote Spark Lend instance.

If the DAI market is fully utilized, interest rates will be temporarily increased to unlock liquidity, based on the withdrawal size and the urgency of the 

AllocatorDAO's request.

To fully understand the muti-chain proposal for Spark Protocol, please check the original post on the Maker Forum

Spark Protocol is live atapp.sparkprotocol.io⚡️

Announcing the Spark Protocol launch ⚡️

Starting May 9, 2023, Spark Protocol will be available to all DeFi users.

An end-user, DAI-centered DeFi product deployed on Ethereum with supply and borrow features for ETH, stETH, DAI, and sDAI.

Spark Protocol's first version, Spark Lend, is a lending marketplace specifically designed for supplying and borrowing crypto with a focus on DAI.
Its users will be able to interact with Spark's front-end directly, connecting Maker's liquidity with a complete DeFi solution.

Spark Protocol is one of many innovations the Endgame Era will bring to the MakerDAO ecosystem, enabling a new groundbreaking solution that could only have arisen from the connection between a DeFi product and the Maker Protocol:

• Spark is connected with Maker's D3M.

This direct wholesale credit line in DAI injects and automatically balances fresh DAI liquidity into Spark Lend and enables its users to access the best rates in the market.

In short, this means that through Spark Lend, users can now borrow DAI at an initial 1.11% annual rate due to the direct injection of liquidity from Maker.
Rates do not increase with utilization, no matter what your size is!

Spark introduces a tokenized version of DAI deposited in the DSR — Savings DAI (sDAI)

Through Spark Lend, users can now employ a yield-bearing version of DAI that is automatically connected to the Dai Savings Rate module.

Worth noting: The Dai Savings Rate’s percentage yield is at 1.00% and may change via Maker Governance’s on-chain voting, which would directly affect Spark Lend’s DAI rates.

• Spark is connected with Maker's PSM.

The Peg Stability Module connects massive liquidity infrastructure for instant swapping of DAI and sDAI for USDC, and vice versa, at a 1:1 rate — Users can now enter DSR from USDC!

It’s time to empower DeFi users with true decentralized, scalable, and top-tier Ethereum-based technology.

With a focus on vertically integrating existing products into Maker and sharing the resulting value creation with developers, Phoenix Labs is a development company that contributes to the innovation of the Spark Protocol product.

The company was assigned the “Ecosystem Actor” role under the new Maker Endgame’s organizational structure.

For further understanding, we encourage you to read the following thread:https://lnkd.in/erveEJ4e

A set of parameter changes for ETH, wstETH, rETH, Curve stETH-ETH LP, and WBTC vault types has been approved by Maker Governance.

🗳️https://lnkd.in/eQCfkfHyCheck out the breakdown below:

↗️ Stability Fee Increases:

• ETH-A from 1.5% to 1.75%.
• ETH-B from 3% to 3.25%.
• ETH-C from 0.75% to 1%.
• WSTETH-A from 1.5% to 1.75%.
• WSTETH-B from 0.75% to 1%.
• RETH-A from 0.5% to 0.75%.
• CRVV1ETHSTETH-A from 1.5% to 1.75%.

↗️ Target Available Debt (gap) Increases:

• WSTETH-A `gap` from 15 million DAI to 30 million DAI.
• WSTETH-B `gap` from 15 million DAI to 30 million DAI.

↘️ Target Available Debt (gap) Reductions:

• WBTC-A gap from 20 million DAI to 10 million DAI.
• WBTC-B gap from 10 million DAI to 5 million DAI.
• WBTC-C gap from 20 million DAI to 10 million DAI.

The rules defined in the DC-IAM smart-contract encourage an amount of 'open space' between the current debt usage and the Debt Ceiling of a vault type.

The Target Available Debt (gap) parameter controls how much of a gap the DC-IAM aims to maintain between the current debt usage and the Debt Ceiling of the vault type.

↗️ Ceiling Increase Cooldown (ttl) Increases:

• WSTETH-A ttl from 21,600 seconds to 43,200 seconds (12 hours)

• WSTETH-B ttl from 28,800 seconds to 57,600 seconds (16 hours)

The Ceiling Increase Cooldown (ttl) parameter controls how frequently the Debt Ceiling can be increased to the next stage defined by the gap parameter.

This is an important notice to all WBTC-A, WBTC-B, WBTC-C, and GNO-A users.

Per the Maker Constitution's Scope Frameworks, the WBTC-A, WBTC-B, WBTC-C, and GNO-A Stability Fees are being increased to 4.9% in order to match the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield.

Article 3.1 of the Decentralized Collateral Scope Framework requires all Maker Core Vaults to have a Stability Fee at least equivalent to the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield to reinforce Dai's stability through appropriate risk management measures.
→https://lnkd.in/euDb_HvAYield Collateral is defined as the portion of the Dai collateral portfolio that is not directly used to enforce the Dai peg, and can be deployed to generate higher yield that results in a surplus to the Maker Protocol.

Further, Article 3.3.5.1 of the Stability and Liquidity Scope Framework establishes that the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield is equivalent to the 3-month US Government Treasury Bill.
→https://lnkd.in/ebMei2BUTo meet this benchmark, the Decentralized Collateral Scope Framework Facilitator has determined that the WBTC-A, WBTC-B, WBTC-C, and GNO-A Stability Fees will be increased to 4.9% through an upcoming Executive Vote.
→https://lnkd.in/euDtZ4KkThese Stability Fee changes will be included in an upcoming Executive Vote, which is expected to take place within the current week.

Once the Executive Vote is enacted by Maker Governance, the new Stability Fee of 4.9% for the aforementioned vault types will be executed 48 hours after the vote’s approval.

It should be noted that all ETH, WSTETH, RETH, and CRVV1ETHSTETH-A vault types are exempt from the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield, according to a vote approved by Maker Governance in early April.
→https://lnkd.in/eDkZvy3j

A general picture of the Maker Protocol smart contract system:

• Core Module: Contains the entire state of the Maker Protocol and controls the central mechanisms of the system while it is in the expected normal state of operation. One of its primary components is the Vat contract. The core Vault, Dai, and collateral state is kept in the Vat.

• Governance Module: Contains the contracts that facilitate MKR voting, proposal execution, and voting security of the Maker Protocol.

• System Stabilizer Module: Corrects the system when the value of the collateral backing Dai drops below the liquidation level (determined by governance) when the stability of the system is at risk.

• Collateral Module: The collateral module is deployed for every new collateral type added to Vat. It contains all the adapters and auction contracts for one specific collateral type.

• Rates Module: Accumulates stability fees on Vault debt balances, as well as interest on Dai Savings Rate (DSR) deposits.

• Dai Module: Contains the DAI token contract and all its key functionalities.

• Oracle Module: An oracle module is deployed for each collateral type, feeding it the price data for a corresponding collateral type to the Vat.

• Proxy Module: Contains contract interfaces, proxies, and aliases to functions necessary for both DSR and Vault management and Maker governance.

• Peg Stability Module: Enables quick swapping of DAI with other stablecoins at a rate of 1:1 by creating a pooled collateralized-debt position with 100% collateralization ratio and 0% stability fees.

• Flash Module: Allows anyone to mint Dai up to a limit set by Maker Governance with the one condition that they pay it all back in the same transaction with a fee.

• Emergency Shutdown Module: It has the ability to trigger the Shutdown of the Maker Protocol.

• MKR Module: Contains the MKR token, which is an ERC20 token that provides a standard ERC20 token interface. It also contains logic for burning and authorized minting of MKR.

• Shutdown: Stops and gracefully settles the Maker Protocol while ensuring that all users, both Dai holders and Vault holders, receive the net value of assets they are entitled to.

For a complete understanding:https://docs.makerdao.com/

Chapter 1:

The Maker Constitution.

To achieve its maximum potential for resiliency, decentralization, and immutability, MakerDAO must establish and enforce robust rules that govern its own organization — The Maker Constitution comes in.

The Maker Constitution is the document that sets immutable rules for the organization, providing the community with a clear path to follow.

This path is meant to limit MakerDAO’s scope, maximize the immutability of the Dai stablecoin with well-defined purposes, and minimize incentive-driven corruption.

The Maker Constitution consists of 11 constitutional articles that serve to establish firm guidelines for MakerDAO.

Our in-depth explanation of each article in one of the most historical Maker Improvement Proposals of MakerDAO is now available on Twitter:https://lnkd.in/eQ2Dfk-u

KISS CVC, a Constitutional Voter Committee focused on simplicity, successfully led the third CVC Subcommittee meeting, marking the end of the first week of CVC meetings.

→https://lnkd.in/eSi7pi9aWhat is a CVC?

Constitutional Voter Committees (CVCs) are groups of MKR holders that publicly coordinate to analyze the best voting behavior based on a particular strategy.

To create a Constitutional Voter Committee, the CVC in question must have at least one registered CVC Member publicly verifying ownership of MKR and pledging their unbreakable support for preserving the Maker Constitution.

KISS CVC is a formalized group of MKR holders within the new Maker Constitution governance structure with a primary focus on ensuring that Dai remains stable, decentralized, open to everybody, and uncensorable.https://lnkd.in/eZyrVV9zKISS CVC's goal is to satisfy DAI and MKR holders, with DAI holders relying on its key characteristics, while MKR holders have invested their money and need to be rewarded financially or otherwise.

Additionally, KISS CVC believes in embracing complexity while pretending simplicity and maintaining simple structures.

They support any scientifically proven method of achieving their goals and reject other proposals.

profile_overview: We built the Maker Protocol, the first open-source, autonomous, and permissionless credit facility
profile_bio:
MakerDAO is the decentralized autonomous organization that enabled and currently sustains the Maker Protocol, the largest decentralized finance protocol by total value locked that generates and maintains Dai, the first decentralized stablecoin.

The Maker Protocol is an open-source smart contract system publicly deployed on Ethereum that anyone can use to generate liquidity by minting the Dai stablecoin.

The tokens that sustain the Maker Protocol are MKR for governance, and DAI as the stablecoin
* MKR is the governance token used by its holders to vote and decide on proposals that aim to improve or change the system.
* DAI is the decentralized stablecoin hard pegged to the US dollar and backed by crypto and legacy finance assets.

The Maker Protocol enables this liquidity via three main products:
* Maker Vaults: A tool where anyone can deposit crypto assets as collateral and generate Dai as a loan against it.
* Peg-Stability Module (PSM): A tool where any user can swap other stablecoins for Dai and vice versa. They can deposit stablecoins and receive Dai at a 1-to-1 rate, or deposit Dai and receive stablecoins held by the PSM at a 1-to-1 rate.
* Direct Deposit Module (D3M): A wholesale credit line that provides immediate liquidity in Dai to lending markets in the decentralized finance space such as Aave.

All the components that make the Maker Protocol work are supported and sustained by the decentralized, open community known as MakerDAO through a decentralized system of Governance powered by MKR token holders and Delegates.

For media inquiry please contact media@makergrowth.com

For business and partnership inquiry please contact partners@makergrowth.com

As of May, MakerDAO's total Real-World Asset (RWA) portfolio reached a value of 2.34 billion DAI.

In terms of distribution, how has this portfolio been allocated, and what outcomes has it produced?

Let's find out ↓

In May, RWAs made up 79.7% of all Stability Fees generated by the Maker Protocol, up from 72.6% in April.

Year to date, this portfolio generated 78.5% of the total Stability Fees.

The RWA Stability Fees for MakerDAO have accumulated to 17,275,121 DAI year-to-date (YTD), and the total RWA Stability Fees since inception amount to 19,453,425 DAI.

Maker's RWA balance increased significantly in May due to the deployment of additional DAI from the Monetalis Clydesdale vault.

The vault increased its debt from 500 million DAI to ~1.14 million DAI.

The Monetalis Clydesdale vault drew an additional 560 million DAI in May.
33% of the vault's assets are 0-1yr treasury ETFs (IB01), 14% are 1-3yr treasury ETFs (IBTA), and the remaining 53% is in a 0-6 month Treasury ladder.

Maker's loan balance in the Huntingdon Valley Bank participation remained at roughly $30 million.

For BlockTower Credit (RWA012 - RWA013), BlockTower drew another 6 million DAI in May and continued to increase the utilization of their second vault.

BlockTower's RWA012 vault now has a debt ceiling of 80 million DAI.

The New Silver deal continues to perform steadily with one covenant (single state exposure) failing by ~6%.

The vault balance is steadily declining.
6s Capital Partners made a new loan for $5.2 million and a previous loan of $1.35 million was repaid. The current loan balance now stands at $12.7 million.

Fortunafi's debt position decreased by about 260k to roughly 5.8 million Dai.
The Harbor Trade transaction has 1.5 million DAI outstanding from the vault.

ConsolFreight's outstanding loan balance sits at 1.4 million Dai, down 400k from the prior month.

This is your opportunity to contribute to the multi-chain future of the Maker ecosystem.

Spark Protocol is going multi-chain, and preparing for its deployments across diverse domains.

If you're interested in deploying Spark Protocol in a specific domain, follow these steps:

↓

First, what are domains?

When we mention 'domains,' we are referring to various blockchain networks, including sidechains and layer 2 solutions.

Now, let's see how to propose a domain deployment for Spark:

The interested domain should create a post on the Maker Forum under the SubDAO TWO category (https://lnkd.in/etmu6ZxH), with the following information:

1) Background Information:

• Who is the interested party for this new domain application?
• Provide a brief high-level overview of the chain
• Explain the business case of having Spark deployed in the new domain.

2) Technical Information:

• Does your team can work on the cross-chain support for L2 Executor and Crosschain Forwarder?
• How long will this take?
• List other technical requirements

3) Collaterals Information

• What would be the initially proposed collaterals besides DAI?

For each collateral please provide:

a. List any possible oracle data sources for the proposed collateral.
b. What is the market cap for the asset?
c. Where does exchange for the asset occur?

4) Liquidity information

• How are you planning to seed liquidity?

After the proposal submission, Phoenix Labs will conduct a domain assessment and offer recommendations to MakerDAO about the new domain and collaterals to be included.

It's essential to note that Spark will only onboard tokens previously approved by Maker.

Additionally, Block Analitica will perform a collateral assessment and suggest risk parameters for the collaterals within Spark in the new domain.

The domain and collateral assessments will be published on the Maker Forum.

These assessments will provide valuable insights for MKR holders when making decisions regarding the deployment of Spark on a new domain.

For a complete understanding, please refer to the original post on the Maker Forum:https://lnkd.in/esbZ6Q7JAlternatively, you can contact the Spark team on Discord:discord.gg/5DFmSaXWJ8.

Stay connected and be a part of this exciting expansion!

Phoenix Labs has proposed a multi-chain future for Spark!

Together, we will strive for the integration of Layer 2 solutions and the exploration of other blockchain networks.

Success lies in being where the users are.

This is a recap of Spark's multi-chain roadmap.

↓

Firstly, Phoenix Lab's proposal outlined key considerations for prioritizing Spark deployments on different chains:

1) Business Case:

Blockchain teams must present a compelling rationale for why Allocators should provide debt capacity to a particular chain.

Allocators won't allocate resources if there is no significant product demand on that chain.

2) Scale:

Spark is looking for domains that can support substantial returns on a large scale, involving hundreds of millions of USD at decent yields.

3) Strategic Value:

Spark prioritizes domains that have strong connections with Maker or the potential to establish such connections within their ecosystem and community.

4) Security + Safety:

The level of venture risk determines the requirements for junior capital.
Spark will prioritize relatively secure chains with higher debt ceilings to maximize profitability.

Phoenix Labs will develop a roadmap that outlines the process of converting Spark Protocol into a multi-chain protocol.

The team has identified two phases to execute this new multi-chain future for Spark:

Phase 1: Permissionless Deployment

In this phase, a fresh instance of Spark Lend will be deployed on the remote chain in coordination with the developer team, ensuring minimal risk for users through a Governance Relay.

During Phase 1, borrow rates will be manually adjusted to closely align with Ethereum's rate.
Important to note:

Domains that are interested in participating should provide essential information in the forum under the SubDAO TWO category.

The forum link is provided below:https://lnkd.in/etmu6ZxHPhase 2: Spark Bridge Deployment

This phase allows AllocatorDAOs to deposit and withdraw funds from the existing Spark Lend instance across different chains.

The Spark Bridge utilizes canonical token bridges to ensure the most liquid version of DAI is utilized.

Withdrawals in Phase 2 are facilitated through AllocatorDAO requests, similar to RWA (Real-World Asset) investments.

A round-trip on the native bridge executes the withdrawal, subject to the availability of liquidity in the remote Spark Lend instance.

If the DAI market is fully utilized, interest rates will be temporarily increased to unlock liquidity, based on the withdrawal size and the urgency of the 

AllocatorDAO's request.

To fully understand the muti-chain proposal for Spark Protocol, please check the original post on the Maker Forum

Please note the following requirements for rETH to remain as an eligible Native Vault Engine collateral type:

By the end of Q3 2023, rETH must achieve a proportional share of revenue compared to the wstETH vault types combined, based on market capitalization of the token.

Failure to meet this requirement will result in the offboarding of rETH, according to article 14.3.

Currently, the market capitalization of stETH is $13.814 billion, while rETH stands at $921 million, resulting in a ratio of 6.67%.

The current rETH/stETH revenue ratio is approximately 4.86%.

Under the current parameter configuration, the outstanding debt of rETH-A needs to increase by $8.13 million to comply with the new rule.

A new Maker Vault now holds a debt surpassing 100 million DAI, which hasn't happened since November 2022!

On June 19th, a WSTETH-A Vault reached a total debt of 105.95 million DAI.

This remarkable amount now stands as the highest debt held by a single Vault in Maker, representing over 52% of all WSTETH-A debt within the system.

Currently, there is another vault approaching this milestone:

A WSTETH-B Vault with a debt of 94.98 million DAI.

Meanwhile, the remaining Vaults range from 10 million to 60 million in debt.

For monitoring Maker Vaults, you can visit:

↓https://lnkd.in/daKwzpJJ

On the left, a year ago: This was the picture of all DAI generated by collateral sources.

On the right, currently:

• ~9% of all DAI is generated from USDC, down from 51%.

• The largest source is RWA007 at 25.5%, which consists of a liquid portfolio of short-term bonds.

• ETH and stETH together represent the second-largest collateral source: ~21.1% of all DAI generated.

Currently, @LidoFinance's stETH is one of the largest assets in crypto — there are over 7 million stETH with over 200k holders.

Similarly, its wrapped version, known as wstETH, has gained immense popularity in DeFi, particularly among the Maker Protocol's users.

wstETH represents right now ~30% of stETH total supply, amounting to ~2 million wstETH tokens.

These wstETH tokens primarily find utility within lending protocols — over 60% of all wstETH is sitting in top-tier DeFi lending apps.

↓https://lnkd.in/e4K8xsNMWith ~932k wstETH, the Maker Protocol's smart contracts hold around 46% of wstETH's total supply.

wstETH holders primarily use their liquid-staked ETH holdings for DAI loans and on-chain leverage.

→https://lnkd.in/eubyEMxawstETH has recently approached wETH in terms of total value locked (TVL) within the Maker Protocol, with wETH currently serving as the largest collateral.

Will we see stETH/ETH flippening soon?

During ETH Prague, Maker took the stage 🎤

Sam, delivered an exceptional presentation on Maker's future within the SubDAO Ecosystem, keeping everyone informed about the latest developments from Endgame.

The stage was set to discuss the future outlook of the DAO, the potential of the SubDAOs Ecosystem, and the role of Governance AI tools in achieving greater decentralization and gamification of DeFi.

A new MakerDAO is on the horizon, more decentralized, more resilient, and more friendly to the DeFi community 🌄

A round of applause for the Phoenix Labs team for their 
outstanding presentation at ETH Prague.

Tadeo from the Phoenix Labs team delivered an amazing analysis of Endgame and shed light on the impact it will have on MakerDAO's organizational and operational structure.

During their presentation, they delved into the relationship between a SubDAO and MakerDAO.

In Spark's case, they highlighted the crucial role of Maker Protocol's D3M in offering direct liquidity to Spark Protocol, establishing a seamless connection with end-users.

Spark is here to provide an easy interface to access the best liquidity with the best DeFi products.

As of today, ~42% of DAI's initial use case goes to DEXes.

Followed by Burn, Treasuries, Lending, and Personal Address holdings.

DAI continues to secure DeFi and its users 🤝

Spark Protocol's DAI borrows maxed out 📈

The DAI borrowed through Spark Protocol has reached its first D3M debt ceiling of 5 million DAI as the total value locked surpasses the $10 million mark!

Some important points to highlight, below ↓

1) The entire 5 million DAI borrowing on Spark Protocol has been achieved at a rate of 1.11% — Spark's borrowing rates remain unaffected by utilization, thanks to the direct injection of liquidity via D3M.

2) An upcoming proposal is about to be voted on by Maker Governance, aiming to raise the Dai Savings Rate (DSR) from 1% to 3.33%. Should this proposal be implemented, it would lead to an increase in Spark's DAI borrowing rates to approximately 3.33%.

3) Another noteworthy proposal, initiated by Phoenix Labs, is about to be voted on to expand Spark's D3M to 20 million DAI.
If approved, this change would enable an extra 15 million DAI to be borrowed through Spark, without any increase in rates due to utilization.

Announcing the Spark Protocol launch ⚡️

Starting May 9, 2023, Spark Protocol will be available to all DeFi users.

An end-user, DAI-centered DeFi product deployed on Ethereum with supply and borrow features for ETH, stETH, DAI, and sDAI.

Spark Protocol's first version, Spark Lend, is a lending marketplace specifically designed for supplying and borrowing crypto with a focus on DAI.
Its users will be able to interact with Spark's front-end directly, connecting Maker's liquidity with a complete DeFi solution.

Spark Protocol is one of many innovations the Endgame Era will bring to the MakerDAO ecosystem, enabling a new groundbreaking solution that could only have arisen from the connection between a DeFi product and the Maker Protocol:

• Spark is connected with Maker's D3M.

This direct wholesale credit line in DAI injects and automatically balances fresh DAI liquidity into Spark Lend and enables its users to access the best rates in the market.

In short, this means that through Spark Lend, users can now borrow DAI at an initial 1.11% annual rate due to the direct injection of liquidity from Maker.
Rates do not increase with utilization, no matter what your size is!

Spark introduces a tokenized version of DAI deposited in the DSR — Savings DAI (sDAI)

Through Spark Lend, users can now employ a yield-bearing version of DAI that is automatically connected to the Dai Savings Rate module.

Worth noting: The Dai Savings Rate’s percentage yield is at 1.00% and may change via Maker Governance’s on-chain voting, which would directly affect Spark Lend’s DAI rates.

• Spark is connected with Maker's PSM.

The Peg Stability Module connects massive liquidity infrastructure for instant swapping of DAI and sDAI for USDC, and vice versa, at a 1:1 rate — Users can now enter DSR from USDC!

It’s time to empower DeFi users with true decentralized, scalable, and top-tier Ethereum-based technology.

With a focus on vertically integrating existing products into Maker and sharing the resulting value creation with developers, Phoenix Labs is a development company that contributes to the innovation of the Spark Protocol product.

The company was assigned the “Ecosystem Actor” role under the new Maker Endgame’s organizational structure.

A set of parameter changes for ETH, wstETH, rETH, Curve stETH-ETH LP, and WBTC vault types has been approved by Maker Governance.

🗳️https://lnkd.in/eQCfkfHyCheck out the breakdown below:

↗️ Stability Fee Increases:

• ETH-A from 1.5% to 1.75%.
• ETH-B from 3% to 3.25%.
• ETH-C from 0.75% to 1%.
• WSTETH-A from 1.5% to 1.75%.
• WSTETH-B from 0.75% to 1%.
• RETH-A from 0.5% to 0.75%.
• CRVV1ETHSTETH-A from 1.5% to 1.75%.

↗️ Target Available Debt (gap) Increases:

• WSTETH-A `gap` from 15 million DAI to 30 million DAI.
• WSTETH-B `gap` from 15 million DAI to 30 million DAI.

↘️ Target Available Debt (gap) Reductions:

• WBTC-A gap from 20 million DAI to 10 million DAI.
• WBTC-B gap from 10 million DAI to 5 million DAI.
• WBTC-C gap from 20 million DAI to 10 million DAI.

The rules defined in the DC-IAM smart-contract encourage an amount of 'open space' between the current debt usage and the Debt Ceiling of a vault type.

The Target Available Debt (gap) parameter controls how much of a gap the DC-IAM aims to maintain between the current debt usage and the Debt Ceiling of the vault type.

↗️ Ceiling Increase Cooldown (ttl) Increases:

• WSTETH-A ttl from 21,600 seconds to 43,200 seconds (12 hours)

• WSTETH-B ttl from 28,800 seconds to 57,600 seconds (16 hours)

The Ceiling Increase Cooldown (ttl) parameter controls how frequently the Debt Ceiling can be increased to the next stage defined by the gap parameter.

This is an important notice to all WBTC-A, WBTC-B, WBTC-C, and GNO-A users.

Per the Maker Constitution's Scope Frameworks, the WBTC-A, WBTC-B, WBTC-C, and GNO-A Stability Fees are being increased to 4.9% in order to match the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield.

Article 3.1 of the Decentralized Collateral Scope Framework requires all Maker Core Vaults to have a Stability Fee at least equivalent to the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield to reinforce Dai's stability through appropriate risk management measures.
→https://lnkd.in/euDb_HvAYield Collateral is defined as the portion of the Dai collateral portfolio that is not directly used to enforce the Dai peg, and can be deployed to generate higher yield that results in a surplus to the Maker Protocol.

Further, Article 3.3.5.1 of the Stability and Liquidity Scope Framework establishes that the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield is equivalent to the 3-month US Government Treasury Bill.
→https://lnkd.in/ebMei2BUTo meet this benchmark, the Decentralized Collateral Scope Framework Facilitator has determined that the WBTC-A, WBTC-B, WBTC-C, and GNO-A Stability Fees will be increased to 4.9% through an upcoming Executive Vote.
→https://lnkd.in/euDtZ4KkThese Stability Fee changes will be included in an upcoming Executive Vote, which is expected to take place within the current week.

Once the Executive Vote is enacted by Maker Governance, the new Stability Fee of 4.9% for the aforementioned vault types will be executed 48 hours after the vote’s approval.

It should be noted that all ETH, WSTETH, RETH, and CRVV1ETHSTETH-A vault types are exempt from the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield, according to a vote approved by Maker Governance in early April.

A general picture of the Maker Protocol smart contract system:

• Core Module: Contains the entire state of the Maker Protocol and controls the central mechanisms of the system while it is in the expected normal state of operation. One of its primary components is the Vat contract. The core Vault, Dai, and collateral state is kept in the Vat.

• Governance Module: Contains the contracts that facilitate MKR voting, proposal execution, and voting security of the Maker Protocol.

• System Stabilizer Module: Corrects the system when the value of the collateral backing Dai drops below the liquidation level (determined by governance) when the stability of the system is at risk.

• Collateral Module: The collateral module is deployed for every new collateral type added to Vat. It contains all the adapters and auction contracts for one specific collateral type.

• Rates Module: Accumulates stability fees on Vault debt balances, as well as interest on Dai Savings Rate (DSR) deposits.

• Dai Module: Contains the DAI token contract and all its key functionalities.

• Oracle Module: An oracle module is deployed for each collateral type, feeding it the price data for a corresponding collateral type to the Vat.

• Proxy Module: Contains contract interfaces, proxies, and aliases to functions necessary for both DSR and Vault management and Maker governance.

• Peg Stability Module: Enables quick swapping of DAI with other stablecoins at a rate of 1:1 by creating a pooled collateralized-debt position with 100% collateralization ratio and 0% stability fees.

• Flash Module: Allows anyone to mint Dai up to a limit set by Maker Governance with the one condition that they pay it all back in the same transaction with a fee.

• Emergency Shutdown Module: It has the ability to trigger the Shutdown of the Maker Protocol.

• MKR Module: Contains the MKR token, which is an ERC20 token that provides a standard ERC20 token interface. It also contains logic for burning and authorized minting of MKR.

• Shutdown: Stops and gracefully settles the Maker Protocol while ensuring that all users, both Dai holders and Vault holders, receive the net value of assets they are entitled to.

For a complete understanding:https://docs.makerdao.com/

Chapter 1:

The Maker Constitution.

To achieve its maximum potential for resiliency, decentralization, and immutability, MakerDAO must establish and enforce robust rules that govern its own organization — The Maker Constitution comes in.

The Maker Constitution is the document that sets immutable rules for the organization, providing the community with a clear path to follow.

This path is meant to limit MakerDAO’s scope, maximize the immutability of the Dai stablecoin with well-defined purposes, and minimize incentive-driven corruption.

The Maker Constitution consists of 11 constitutional articles that serve to establish firm guidelines for MakerDAO.

Our in-depth explanation of each article in one of the most historical Maker Improvement Proposals of MakerDAO is now available on Twitter:https://lnkd.in/eQ2Dfk-u

profile_overview: We built the Maker Protocol, the first open-source, autonomous, and permissionless credit facility
profile_bio:
MakerDAO is the decentralized autonomous organization that enabled and currently sustains the Maker Protocol, the largest decentralized finance protocol by total value locked that generates and maintains Dai, the first decentralized stablecoin.

The Maker Protocol is an open-source smart contract system publicly deployed on Ethereum that anyone can use to generate liquidity by minting the Dai stablecoin.

The tokens that sustain the Maker Protocol are MKR for governance, and DAI as the stablecoin
* MKR is the governance token used by its holders to vote and decide on proposals that aim to improve or change the system.
* DAI is the decentralized stablecoin hard pegged to the US dollar and backed by crypto and legacy finance assets.

The Maker Protocol enables this liquidity via three main products:
* Maker Vaults: A tool where anyone can deposit crypto assets as collateral and generate Dai as a loan against it.
* Peg-Stability Module (PSM): A tool where any user can swap other stablecoins for Dai and vice versa. They can deposit stablecoins and receive Dai at a 1-to-1 rate, or deposit Dai and receive stablecoins held by the PSM at a 1-to-1 rate.
* Direct Deposit Module (D3M): A wholesale credit line that provides immediate liquidity in Dai to lending markets in the decentralized finance space such as Aave.

All the components that make the Maker Protocol work are supported and sustained by the decentralized, open community known as MakerDAO through a decentralized system of Governance powered by MKR token holders and Delegates.

For media inquiry please contact media@makergrowth.com

For business and partnership inquiry please contact partners@makergrowth.com

As of May, MakerDAO's total Real-World Asset (RWA) portfolio reached a value of 2.34 billion DAI.

In terms of distribution, how has this portfolio been allocated, and what outcomes has it produced?

Let's find out ↓

In May, RWAs made up 79.7% of all Stability Fees generated by the Maker Protocol, up from 72.6% in April.

Year to date, this portfolio generated 78.5% of the total Stability Fees.

The RWA Stability Fees for MakerDAO have accumulated to 17,275,121 DAI year-to-date (YTD), and the total RWA Stability Fees since inception amount to 19,453,425 DAI.

Maker's RWA balance increased significantly in May due to the deployment of additional DAI from the Monetalis Clydesdale vault.

The vault increased its debt from 500 million DAI to ~1.14 million DAI.

The Monetalis Clydesdale vault drew an additional 560 million DAI in May.
33% of the vault's assets are 0-1yr treasury ETFs (IB01), 14% are 1-3yr treasury ETFs (IBTA), and the remaining 53% is in a 0-6 month Treasury ladder.

Maker's loan balance in the Huntingdon Valley Bank participation remained at roughly $30 million.

For BlockTower Credit (RWA012 - RWA013), BlockTower drew another 6 million DAI in May and continued to increase the utilization of their second vault.

BlockTower's RWA012 vault now has a debt ceiling of 80 million DAI.

The New Silver deal continues to perform steadily with one covenant (single state exposure) failing by ~6%.

The vault balance is steadily declining.
6s Capital Partners made a new loan for $5.2 million and a previous loan of $1.35 million was repaid. The current loan balance now stands at $12.7 million.

Fortunafi's debt position decreased by about 260k to roughly 5.8 million Dai.
The Harbor Trade transaction has 1.5 million DAI outstanding from the vault.

ConsolFreight's outstanding loan balance sits at 1.4 million Dai, down 400k from the prior month.

This is your opportunity to contribute to the multi-chain future of the Maker ecosystem.

Spark Protocol is going multi-chain, and preparing for its deployments across diverse domains.

If you're interested in deploying Spark Protocol in a specific domain, follow these steps:

↓

First, what are domains?

When we mention 'domains,' we are referring to various blockchain networks, including sidechains and layer 2 solutions.

Now, let's see how to propose a domain deployment for Spark:

The interested domain should create a post on the Maker Forum under the SubDAO TWO category (https://lnkd.in/etmu6ZxH), with the following information:

1) Background Information:

• Who is the interested party for this new domain application?
• Provide a brief high-level overview of the chain
• Explain the business case of having Spark deployed in the new domain.

2) Technical Information:

• Does your team can work on the cross-chain support for L2 Executor and Crosschain Forwarder?
• How long will this take?
• List other technical requirements

3) Collaterals Information

• What would be the initially proposed collaterals besides DAI?

For each collateral please provide:

a. List any possible oracle data sources for the proposed collateral.
b. What is the market cap for the asset?
c. Where does exchange for the asset occur?

4) Liquidity information

• How are you planning to seed liquidity?

After the proposal submission, Phoenix Labs will conduct a domain assessment and offer recommendations to MakerDAO about the new domain and collaterals to be included.

It's essential to note that Spark will only onboard tokens previously approved by Maker.

Additionally, Block Analitica will perform a collateral assessment and suggest risk parameters for the collaterals within Spark in the new domain.

The domain and collateral assessments will be published on the Maker Forum.

These assessments will provide valuable insights for MKR holders when making decisions regarding the deployment of Spark on a new domain.

For a complete understanding, please refer to the original post on the Maker Forum:https://lnkd.in/esbZ6Q7JAlternatively, you can contact the Spark team on Discord:discord.gg/5DFmSaXWJ8.

Stay connected and be a part of this exciting expansion!

Phoenix Labs has proposed a multi-chain future for Spark!

Together, we will strive for the integration of Layer 2 solutions and the exploration of other blockchain networks.

Success lies in being where the users are.

This is a recap of Spark's multi-chain roadmap.

↓

Firstly, Phoenix Lab's proposal outlined key considerations for prioritizing Spark deployments on different chains:

1) Business Case:

Blockchain teams must present a compelling rationale for why Allocators should provide debt capacity to a particular chain.

Allocators won't allocate resources if there is no significant product demand on that chain.

2) Scale:

Spark is looking for domains that can support substantial returns on a large scale, involving hundreds of millions of USD at decent yields.

3) Strategic Value:

Spark prioritizes domains that have strong connections with Maker or the potential to establish such connections within their ecosystem and community.

4) Security + Safety:

The level of venture risk determines the requirements for junior capital.
Spark will prioritize relatively secure chains with higher debt ceilings to maximize profitability.

Phoenix Labs will develop a roadmap that outlines the process of converting Spark Protocol into a multi-chain protocol.

The team has identified two phases to execute this new multi-chain future for Spark:

Phase 1: Permissionless Deployment

In this phase, a fresh instance of Spark Lend will be deployed on the remote chain in coordination with the developer team, ensuring minimal risk for users through a Governance Relay.

During Phase 1, borrow rates will be manually adjusted to closely align with Ethereum's rate.
Important to note:

Domains that are interested in participating should provide essential information in the forum under the SubDAO TWO category.

The forum link is provided below:https://lnkd.in/etmu6ZxHPhase 2: Spark Bridge Deployment

This phase allows AllocatorDAOs to deposit and withdraw funds from the existing Spark Lend instance across different chains.

The Spark Bridge utilizes canonical token bridges to ensure the most liquid version of DAI is utilized.

Withdrawals in Phase 2 are facilitated through AllocatorDAO requests, similar to RWA (Real-World Asset) investments.

A round-trip on the native bridge executes the withdrawal, subject to the availability of liquidity in the remote Spark Lend instance.

If the DAI market is fully utilized, interest rates will be temporarily increased to unlock liquidity, based on the withdrawal size and the urgency of the 

AllocatorDAO's request.

To fully understand the muti-chain proposal for Spark Protocol, please check the original post on the Maker Forum

Block Analiticahas submitted a series of parameter changes to the Maker Protocol for an Executive Vote, in line with the Stability Scope requirements.https://lnkd.in/ejq_QyAi↓

📉 Here are the proposed reductions in Stability Fees:

• Reduce the ETH-A Stability Fee from 3.74% to 3.45%.
• Reduce the ETH-B Stability Fee from 4.24% to 3.95%.
• Reduce the ETH-C Stability Fee from 3.49% to 3.20%.
• Reduce the WSTETH-A Stability Fee from 3.74% to 3.45%.
• Reduce the WSTETH-B Stability Fee from 3.49% to 3.20%.
• Reduce the RETH-A Stability Fee from 3.74% to 3.45%.
• Reduce the WBTC-A Stability Fee from 5.80% to 5.69%.
• Reduce the WBTC-B Stability Fee from 6.30% to 6.19%.
• Reduce the WBTC-C Stability Fee from 5.55% to 5.44%.

📉 Additionally, there will be reductions in Liquidation Ratios (mat):

• Reduce the WSTETH-A Liquidation Ratio (mat) from 160% to 150%.
• Reduce the WSTETH-B Liquidation Ratio (mat) from 185% to 175%.
• Reduce the RETH-A Liquidation Ratio (mat) from 170% to 150%.

Other changes include a reduction in the Base Rate from 4.09% to 3.80%, a reduction in the Dai Savings Rate (DSR) from 3.49% to 3.20%, and setting the CRVV1ETHSTETH-A Debt Ceiling (line) to 0.

Please note the following requirements for rETH to remain as an eligible Native Vault Engine collateral type:

By the end of Q3 2023, rETH must achieve a proportional share of revenue compared to the wstETH vault types combined, based on market capitalization of the token.

Failure to meet this requirement will result in the offboarding of rETH, according to article 14.3.

Currently, the market capitalization of stETH is $13.814 billion, while rETH stands at $921 million, resulting in a ratio of 6.67%.

The current rETH/stETH revenue ratio is approximately 4.86%.

Under the current parameter configuration, the outstanding debt of rETH-A needs to increase by $8.13 million to comply with the new rule.

For a detailed explanation of the proposed changes, please refer to the original post in the Maker Forum.

Announcing the Spark Protocol launch ⚡️

Starting May 9, 2023, Spark Protocol will be available to all DeFi users.

An end-user, DAI-centered DeFi product deployed on Ethereum with supply and borrow features for ETH, stETH, DAI, and sDAI.

Spark Protocol's first version, Spark Lend, is a lending marketplace specifically designed for supplying and borrowing crypto with a focus on DAI.
Its users will be able to interact with Spark's front-end directly, connecting Maker's liquidity with a complete DeFi solution.

Spark Protocol is one of many innovations the Endgame Era will bring to the MakerDAO ecosystem, enabling a new groundbreaking solution that could only have arisen from the connection between a DeFi product and the Maker Protocol:

• Spark is connected with Maker's D3M.

This direct wholesale credit line in DAI injects and automatically balances fresh DAI liquidity into Spark Lend and enables its users to access the best rates in the market.

In short, this means that through Spark Lend, users can now borrow DAI at an initial 1.11% annual rate due to the direct injection of liquidity from Maker.
Rates do not increase with utilization, no matter what your size is!

Spark introduces a tokenized version of DAI deposited in the DSR — Savings DAI (sDAI)

Through Spark Lend, users can now employ a yield-bearing version of DAI that is automatically connected to the Dai Savings Rate module.

Worth noting: The Dai Savings Rate’s percentage yield is at 1.00% and may change via Maker Governance’s on-chain voting, which would directly affect Spark Lend’s DAI rates.

• Spark is connected with Maker's PSM.

The Peg Stability Module connects massive liquidity infrastructure for instant swapping of DAI and sDAI for USDC, and vice versa, at a 1:1 rate — Users can now enter DSR from USDC!

It’s time to empower DeFi users with true decentralized, scalable, and top-tier Ethereum-based technology.

With a focus on vertically integrating existing products into Maker and sharing the resulting value creation with developers, Phoenix Labs is a development company that contributes to the innovation of the Spark Protocol product.

The company was assigned the “Ecosystem Actor” role under the new Maker Endgame’s organizational structure.

The rules defined in the DC-IAM smart-contract encourage an amount of 'open space' between the current debt usage and the Debt Ceiling of a vault type.

This is an important notice to all WBTC-A, WBTC-B, WBTC-C, and GNO-A users.

Per the Maker Constitution's Scope Frameworks, the WBTC-A, WBTC-B, WBTC-C, and GNO-A Stability Fees are being increased to 4.9% in order to match the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield.

Article 3.1 of the Decentralized Collateral Scope Framework requires all Maker Core Vaults to have a Stability Fee at least equivalent to the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield to reinforce Dai's stability through appropriate risk management measures.
→https://lnkd.in/euDb_HvAYield Collateral is defined as the portion of the Dai collateral portfolio that is not directly used to enforce the Dai peg, and can be deployed to generate higher yield that results in a surplus to the Maker Protocol.

Further, Article 3.3.5.1 of the Stability and Liquidity Scope Framework establishes that the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield is equivalent to the 3-month US Government Treasury Bill.
→https://lnkd.in/ebMei2BUTo meet this benchmark, the Decentralized Collateral Scope Framework Facilitator has determined that the WBTC-A, WBTC-B, WBTC-C, and GNO-A Stability Fees will be increased to 4.9% through an upcoming Executive Vote.
→https://lnkd.in/euDtZ4KkThese Stability Fee changes will be included in an upcoming Executive Vote, which is expected to take place within the current week.

Once the Executive Vote is enacted by Maker Governance, the new Stability Fee of 4.9% for the aforementioned vault types will be executed 48 hours after the vote’s approval.

It should be noted that all ETH, WSTETH, RETH, and CRVV1ETHSTETH-A vault types are exempt from the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield, according to a vote approved by Maker Governance in early April.

A general picture of the Maker Protocol smart contract system:

• Core Module: Contains the entire state of the Maker Protocol and controls the central mechanisms of the system while it is in the expected normal state of operation. One of its primary components is the Vat contract. The core Vault, Dai, and collateral state is kept in the Vat.

• Governance Module: Contains the contracts that facilitate MKR voting, proposal execution, and voting security of the Maker Protocol.

• System Stabilizer Module: Corrects the system when the value of the collateral backing Dai drops below the liquidation level (determined by governance) when the stability of the system is at risk.

• Collateral Module: The collateral module is deployed for every new collateral type added to Vat. It contains all the adapters and auction contracts for one specific collateral type.

• Rates Module: Accumulates stability fees on Vault debt balances, as well as interest on Dai Savings Rate (DSR) deposits.

• Dai Module: Contains the DAI token contract and all its key functionalities.

• Oracle Module: An oracle module is deployed for each collateral type, feeding it the price data for a corresponding collateral type to the Vat.

• Proxy Module: Contains contract interfaces, proxies, and aliases to functions necessary for both DSR and Vault management and Maker governance.

• Peg Stability Module: Enables quick swapping of DAI with other stablecoins at a rate of 1:1 by creating a pooled collateralized-debt position with 100% collateralization ratio and 0% stability fees.

• Flash Module: Allows anyone to mint Dai up to a limit set by Maker Governance with the one condition that they pay it all back in the same transaction with a fee.

• Emergency Shutdown Module: It has the ability to trigger the Shutdown of the Maker Protocol.

• MKR Module: Contains the MKR token, which is an ERC20 token that provides a standard ERC20 token interface. It also contains logic for burning and authorized minting of MKR.

• Shutdown: Stops and gracefully settles the Maker Protocol while ensuring that all users, both Dai holders and Vault holders, receive the net value of assets they are entitled to.

For a complete understanding:https://docs.makerdao.com/

profile_overview: We built the Maker Protocol, the first open-source, autonomous, and permissionless credit facility
profile_bio:
MakerDAO is the decentralized autonomous organization that enabled and currently sustains the Maker Protocol, the largest decentralized finance protocol by total value locked that generates and maintains Dai, the first decentralized stablecoin.

The Maker Protocol is an open-source smart contract system publicly deployed on Ethereum that anyone can use to generate liquidity by minting the Dai stablecoin.

The tokens that sustain the Maker Protocol are MKR for governance, and DAI as the stablecoin
* MKR is the governance token used by its holders to vote and decide on proposals that aim to improve or change the system.
* DAI is the decentralized stablecoin hard pegged to the US dollar and backed by crypto and legacy finance assets.

The Maker Protocol enables this liquidity via three main products:
* Maker Vaults: A tool where anyone can deposit crypto assets as collateral and generate Dai as a loan against it.
* Peg-Stability Module (PSM): A tool where any user can swap other stablecoins for Dai and vice versa. They can deposit stablecoins and receive Dai at a 1-to-1 rate, or deposit Dai and receive stablecoins held by the PSM at a 1-to-1 rate.
* Direct Deposit Module (D3M): A wholesale credit line that provides immediate liquidity in Dai to lending markets in the decentralized finance space such as Aave.

All the components that make the Maker Protocol work are supported and sustained by the decentralized, open community known as MakerDAO through a decentralized system of Governance powered by MKR token holders and Delegates.

For media inquiry please contact media@makergrowth.com

For business and partnership inquiry please contact partners@makergrowth.com

As of May, MakerDAO's total Real-World Asset (RWA) portfolio reached a value of 2.34 billion DAI.

In terms of distribution, how has this portfolio been allocated, and what outcomes has it produced?

Let's find out ↓

In May, RWAs made up 79.7% of all Stability Fees generated by the Maker Protocol, up from 72.6% in April.

Year to date, this portfolio generated 78.5% of the total Stability Fees.

The RWA Stability Fees for MakerDAO have accumulated to 17,275,121 DAI year-to-date (YTD), and the total RWA Stability Fees since inception amount to 19,453,425 DAI.

Maker's RWA balance increased significantly in May due to the deployment of additional DAI from the Monetalis Clydesdale vault.

The vault increased its debt from 500 million DAI to ~1.14 million DAI.

The Monetalis Clydesdale vault drew an additional 560 million DAI in May.
33% of the vault's assets are 0-1yr treasury ETFs (IB01), 14% are 1-3yr treasury ETFs (IBTA), and the remaining 53% is in a 0-6 month Treasury ladder.

Maker's loan balance in the Huntingdon Valley Bank participation remained at roughly $30 million.

For BlockTower Credit (RWA012 - RWA013), BlockTower drew another 6 million DAI in May and continued to increase the utilization of their second vault.

BlockTower's RWA012 vault now has a debt ceiling of 80 million DAI.

The New Silver deal continues to perform steadily with one covenant (single state exposure) failing by ~6%.

The vault balance is steadily declining.
6s Capital Partners made a new loan for $5.2 million and a previous loan of $1.35 million was repaid. The current loan balance now stands at $12.7 million.

Fortunafi's debt position decreased by about 260k to roughly 5.8 million Dai.
The Harbor Trade transaction has 1.5 million DAI outstanding from the vault.

ConsolFreight's outstanding loan balance sits at 1.4 million Dai, down 400k from the prior month.

This is your opportunity to contribute to the multi-chain future of the Maker ecosystem.

Spark Protocol is going multi-chain, and preparing for its deployments across diverse domains.

If you're interested in deploying Spark Protocol in a specific domain, follow these steps:

↓

First, what are domains?

When we mention 'domains,' we are referring to various blockchain networks, including sidechains and layer 2 solutions.

Now, let's see how to propose a domain deployment for Spark:

The interested domain should create a post on the Maker Forum under the SubDAO TWO category (https://lnkd.in/etmu6ZxH), with the following information:

1) Background Information:

• Who is the interested party for this new domain application?
• Provide a brief high-level overview of the chain
• Explain the business case of having Spark deployed in the new domain.

2) Technical Information:

• Does your team can work on the cross-chain support for L2 Executor and Crosschain Forwarder?
• How long will this take?
• List other technical requirements

3) Collaterals Information

• What would be the initially proposed collaterals besides DAI?

For each collateral please provide:

a. List any possible oracle data sources for the proposed collateral.
b. What is the market cap for the asset?
c. Where does exchange for the asset occur?

4) Liquidity information

• How are you planning to seed liquidity?

After the proposal submission, Phoenix Labs will conduct a domain assessment and offer recommendations to MakerDAO about the new domain and collaterals to be included.

It's essential to note that Spark will only onboard tokens previously approved by Maker.

Additionally, Block Analitica will perform a collateral assessment and suggest risk parameters for the collaterals within Spark in the new domain.

The domain and collateral assessments will be published on the Maker Forum.

These assessments will provide valuable insights for MKR holders when making decisions regarding the deployment of Spark on a new domain.

For a complete understanding, please refer to the original post on the Maker Forum:https://lnkd.in/esbZ6Q7JAlternatively, you can contact the Spark team on Discord:discord.gg/5DFmSaXWJ8.

Stay connected and be a part of this exciting expansion!

Phoenix Labs has proposed a multi-chain future for Spark!

Together, we will strive for the integration of Layer 2 solutions and the exploration of other blockchain networks.

Success lies in being where the users are.

This is a recap of Spark's multi-chain roadmap.

↓

Firstly, Phoenix Lab's proposal outlined key considerations for prioritizing Spark deployments on different chains:

1) Business Case:

Blockchain teams must present a compelling rationale for why Allocators should provide debt capacity to a particular chain.

Allocators won't allocate resources if there is no significant product demand on that chain.

2) Scale:

Spark is looking for domains that can support substantial returns on a large scale, involving hundreds of millions of USD at decent yields.

3) Strategic Value:

Spark prioritizes domains that have strong connections with Maker or the potential to establish such connections within their ecosystem and community.

4) Security + Safety:

The level of venture risk determines the requirements for junior capital.
Spark will prioritize relatively secure chains with higher debt ceilings to maximize profitability.

Phoenix Labs will develop a roadmap that outlines the process of converting Spark Protocol into a multi-chain protocol.

The team has identified two phases to execute this new multi-chain future for Spark:

Phase 1: Permissionless Deployment

In this phase, a fresh instance of Spark Lend will be deployed on the remote chain in coordination with the developer team, ensuring minimal risk for users through a Governance Relay.

During Phase 1, borrow rates will be manually adjusted to closely align with Ethereum's rate.
Important to note:

Domains that are interested in participating should provide essential information in the forum under the SubDAO TWO category.

The forum link is provided below:https://lnkd.in/etmu6ZxHPhase 2: Spark Bridge Deployment

This phase allows AllocatorDAOs to deposit and withdraw funds from the existing Spark Lend instance across different chains.

The Spark Bridge utilizes canonical token bridges to ensure the most liquid version of DAI is utilized.

Withdrawals in Phase 2 are facilitated through AllocatorDAO requests, similar to RWA (Real-World Asset) investments.

A round-trip on the native bridge executes the withdrawal, subject to the availability of liquidity in the remote Spark Lend instance.

If the DAI market is fully utilized, interest rates will be temporarily increased to unlock liquidity, based on the withdrawal size and the urgency of the 

AllocatorDAO's request.

To fully understand the muti-chain proposal for Spark Protocol, please check the original post on the Maker Forum

Block Analiticahas submitted a series of parameter changes to the Maker Protocol for an Executive Vote, in line with the Stability Scope requirements.https://lnkd.in/ejq_QyAi↓

📉 Here are the proposed reductions in Stability Fees:

• Reduce the ETH-A Stability Fee from 3.74% to 3.45%.
• Reduce the ETH-B Stability Fee from 4.24% to 3.95%.
• Reduce the ETH-C Stability Fee from 3.49% to 3.20%.
• Reduce the WSTETH-A Stability Fee from 3.74% to 3.45%.
• Reduce the WSTETH-B Stability Fee from 3.49% to 3.20%.
• Reduce the RETH-A Stability Fee from 3.74% to 3.45%.
• Reduce the WBTC-A Stability Fee from 5.80% to 5.69%.
• Reduce the WBTC-B Stability Fee from 6.30% to 6.19%.
• Reduce the WBTC-C Stability Fee from 5.55% to 5.44%.

📉 Additionally, there will be reductions in Liquidation Ratios (mat):

• Reduce the WSTETH-A Liquidation Ratio (mat) from 160% to 150%.
• Reduce the WSTETH-B Liquidation Ratio (mat) from 185% to 175%.
• Reduce the RETH-A Liquidation Ratio (mat) from 170% to 150%.

Other changes include a reduction in the Base Rate from 4.09% to 3.80%, a reduction in the Dai Savings Rate (DSR) from 3.49% to 3.20%, and setting the CRVV1ETHSTETH-A Debt Ceiling (line) to 0.

Please note the following requirements for rETH to remain as an eligible Native Vault Engine collateral type:

By the end of Q3 2023, rETH must achieve a proportional share of revenue compared to the wstETH vault types combined, based on market capitalization of the token.

Failure to meet this requirement will result in the offboarding of rETH, according to article 14.3.

Currently, the market capitalization of stETH is $13.814 billion, while rETH stands at $921 million, resulting in a ratio of 6.67%.

The current rETH/stETH revenue ratio is approximately 4.86%.

Under the current parameter configuration, the outstanding debt of rETH-A needs to increase by $8.13 million to comply with the new rule.

For a detailed explanation of the proposed changes, please refer to the original post in the Maker Forum.

Announcing the Spark Protocol launch ⚡️

Starting May 9, 2023, Spark Protocol will be available to all DeFi users.

An end-user, DAI-centered DeFi product deployed on Ethereum with supply and borrow features for ETH, stETH, DAI, and sDAI.

Spark Protocol's first version, Spark Lend, is a lending marketplace specifically designed for supplying and borrowing crypto with a focus on DAI.
Its users will be able to interact with Spark's front-end directly, connecting Maker's liquidity with a complete DeFi solution.

Spark Protocol is one of many innovations the Endgame Era will bring to the MakerDAO ecosystem, enabling a new groundbreaking solution that could only have arisen from the connection between a DeFi product and the Maker Protocol:

• Spark is connected with Maker's D3M.

This direct wholesale credit line in DAI injects and automatically balances fresh DAI liquidity into Spark Lend and enables its users to access the best rates in the market.

In short, this means that through Spark Lend, users can now borrow DAI at an initial 1.11% annual rate due to the direct injection of liquidity from Maker.
Rates do not increase with utilization, no matter what your size is!

Spark introduces a tokenized version of DAI deposited in the DSR — Savings DAI (sDAI)

Through Spark Lend, users can now employ a yield-bearing version of DAI that is automatically connected to the Dai Savings Rate module.

Worth noting: The Dai Savings Rate’s percentage yield is at 1.00% and may change via Maker Governance’s on-chain voting, which would directly affect Spark Lend’s DAI rates.

• Spark is connected with Maker's PSM.

The Peg Stability Module connects massive liquidity infrastructure for instant swapping of DAI and sDAI for USDC, and vice versa, at a 1:1 rate — Users can now enter DSR from USDC!

It’s time to empower DeFi users with true decentralized, scalable, and top-tier Ethereum-based technology.

With a focus on vertically integrating existing products into Maker and sharing the resulting value creation with developers, Phoenix Labs is a development company that contributes to the innovation of the Spark Protocol product.

The company was assigned the “Ecosystem Actor” role under the new Maker Endgame’s organizational structure.

For further understanding, we encourage you to read the following thread:https://lnkd.in/erveEJ4e

The rules defined in the DC-IAM smart-contract encourage an amount of 'open space' between the current debt usage and the Debt Ceiling of a vault type.

The Target Available Debt (gap) parameter controls how much of a gap the DC-IAM aims to maintain between the current debt usage and the Debt Ceiling of the vault type.

↗️ Ceiling Increase Cooldown (ttl) Increases:

• WSTETH-A ttl from 21,600 seconds to 43,200 seconds (12 hours)

• WSTETH-B ttl from 28,800 seconds to 57,600 seconds (16 hours)

The Ceiling Increase Cooldown (ttl) parameter controls how frequently the Debt Ceiling can be increased to the next stage defined by the gap parameter.

This is an important notice to all WBTC-A, WBTC-B, WBTC-C, and GNO-A users.

Per the Maker Constitution's Scope Frameworks, the WBTC-A, WBTC-B, WBTC-C, and GNO-A Stability Fees are being increased to 4.9% in order to match the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield.

Article 3.1 of the Decentralized Collateral Scope Framework requires all Maker Core Vaults to have a Stability Fee at least equivalent to the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield to reinforce Dai's stability through appropriate risk management measures.
→https://lnkd.in/euDb_HvAYield Collateral is defined as the portion of the Dai collateral portfolio that is not directly used to enforce the Dai peg, and can be deployed to generate higher yield that results in a surplus to the Maker Protocol.

Further, Article 3.3.5.1 of the Stability and Liquidity Scope Framework establishes that the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield is equivalent to the 3-month US Government Treasury Bill.
→https://lnkd.in/ebMei2BUTo meet this benchmark, the Decentralized Collateral Scope Framework Facilitator has determined that the WBTC-A, WBTC-B, WBTC-C, and GNO-A Stability Fees will be increased to 4.9% through an upcoming Executive Vote.
→https://lnkd.in/euDtZ4KkThese Stability Fee changes will be included in an upcoming Executive Vote, which is expected to take place within the current week.

Once the Executive Vote is enacted by Maker Governance, the new Stability Fee of 4.9% for the aforementioned vault types will be executed 48 hours after the vote’s approval.

It should be noted that all ETH, WSTETH, RETH, and CRVV1ETHSTETH-A vault types are exempt from the Yield Collateral Benchmark Yield, according to a vote approved by Maker Governance in early April.
→https://lnkd.in/eDkZvy3j

A general picture of the Maker Protocol smart contract system:

• Core Module: Contains the entire state of the Maker Protocol and controls the central mechanisms of the system while it is in the expected normal state of operation. One of its primary components is the Vat contract. The core Vault, Dai, and collateral state is kept in the Vat.

• Governance Module: Contains the contracts that facilitate MKR voting, proposal execution, and voting security of the Maker Protocol.

• System Stabilizer Module: Corrects the system when the value of the collateral backing Dai drops below the liquidation level (determined by governance) when the stability of the system is at risk.

• Collateral Module: The collateral module is deployed for every new collateral type added to Vat. It contains all the adapters and auction contracts for one specific collateral type.

• Rates Module: Accumulates stability fees on Vault debt balances, as well as interest on Dai Savings Rate (DSR) deposits.

• Dai Module: Contains the DAI token contract and all its key functionalities.

• Oracle Module: An oracle module is deployed for each collateral type, feeding it the price data for a corresponding collateral type to the Vat.

• Proxy Module: Contains contract interfaces, proxies, and aliases to functions necessary for both DSR and Vault management and Maker governance.

• Peg Stability Module: Enables quick swapping of DAI with other stablecoins at a rate of 1:1 by creating a pooled collateralized-debt position with 100% collateralization ratio and 0% stability fees.

• Flash Module: Allows anyone to mint Dai up to a limit set by Maker Governance with the one condition that they pay it all back in the same transaction with a fee.

• Emergency Shutdown Module: It has the ability to trigger the Shutdown of the Maker Protocol.

• MKR Module: Contains the MKR token, which is an ERC20 token that provides a standard ERC20 token interface. It also contains logic for burning and authorized minting of MKR.

• Shutdown: Stops and gracefully settles the Maker Protocol while ensuring that all users, both Dai holders and Vault holders, receive the net value of assets they are entitled to.

For a complete understanding:https://docs.makerdao.com/

profile_overview: We built the Maker Protocol, the first open-source, autonomous, and permissionless credit facility
profile_bio:
MakerDAO is the decentralized autonomous organization that enabled and currently sustains the Maker Protocol, the largest decentralized finance protocol by total value locked that generates and maintains Dai, the first decentralized stablecoin.

The Maker Protocol is an open-source smart contract system publicly deployed on Ethereum that anyone can use to generate liquidity by minting the Dai stablecoin.

The tokens that sustain the Maker Protocol are MKR for governance, and DAI as the stablecoin
* MKR is the governance token used by its holders to vote and decide on proposals that aim to improve or change the system.
* DAI is the decentralized stablecoin hard pegged to the US dollar and backed by crypto and legacy finance assets.

The Maker Protocol enables this liquidity via three main products:
* Maker Vaults: A tool where anyone can deposit crypto assets as collateral and generate Dai as a loan against it.
* Peg-Stability Module (PSM): A tool where any user can swap other stablecoins for Dai and vice versa. They can deposit stablecoins and receive Dai at a 1-to-1 rate, or deposit Dai and receive stablecoins held by the PSM at a 1-to-1 rate.
* Direct Deposit Module (D3M): A wholesale credit line that provides immediate liquidity in Dai to lending markets in the decentralized finance space such as Aave.

All the components that make the Maker Protocol work are supported and sustained by the decentralized, open community known as MakerDAO through a decentralized system of Governance powered by MKR token holders and Delegates.

For media inquiry please contact media@makergrowth.com

For business and partnership inquiry please contact partners@makergrowth.com

Important notice to all CRVV1ETHSTETH-A users.

The CRVV1ETHSTETH-A vault type is being offboarded from the Maker Protocol.

↓

• Set the CRVV1ETHSTETH-A Debt Ceiling to 0 DAI.

Please note that a forthcoming Executive Vote will conclude the offboarding process for CRVV1ETHSTETH-A in the coming weeks.

This will involve the liquidation of all remaining vaults and the removal of the vault type from the Maker Protocol system.

If as a CRVV1ETHSTETH-A user you want to avoid liquidation, we strongly recommend that you pay off your DAI debt in full and close all your CRVV1ETHSTETH-A vaults before the deployment of the final Executive Vote.

As of May, MakerDAO's total Real-World Asset (RWA) portfolio reached a value of 2.34 billion DAI.

In terms of distribution, how has this portfolio been allocated, and what outcomes has it produced?

Let's find out ↓

In May, RWAs made up 79.7% of all Stability Fees generated by the Maker Protocol, up from 72.6% in April.

Year to date, this portfolio generated 78.5% of the total Stability Fees.

The RWA Stability Fees for MakerDAO have accumulated to 17,275,121 DAI year-to-date (YTD), and the total RWA Stability Fees since inception amount to 19,453,425 DAI.

Maker's RWA balance increased significantly in May due to the deployment of additional DAI from the Monetalis Clydesdale vault.

The vault increased its debt from 500 million DAI to ~1.14 million DAI.

The Monetalis Clydesdale vault drew an additional 560 million DAI in May.
33% of the vault's assets are 0-1yr treasury ETFs (IB01), 14% are 1-3yr treasury ETFs (IBTA), and the remaining 53% is in a 0-6 month Treasury ladder.

Maker's loan balance in the Huntingdon Valley Bank participation remained at roughly $30 million.

For BlockTower Credit (RWA012 - RWA013), BlockTower drew another 6 million DAI in May and continued to increase the utilization of their second vault.

BlockTower's RWA012 vault now has a debt ceiling of 80 million DAI.

The New Silver deal continues to perform steadily with one covenant (single state exposure) failing by ~6%.

The vault balance is steadily declining.
6s Capital Partners made a new loan for $5.2 million and a previous loan of $1.35 million was repaid. The current loan balance now stands at $12.7 million.

Fortunafi's debt position decreased by about 260k to roughly 5.8 million Dai.
The Harbor Trade transaction has 1.5 million DAI outstanding from the vault.

ConsolFreight's outstanding loan balance sits at 1.4 million Dai, down 400k from the prior month.
